name: Train Valley
description: Build railways, manage traffic and stay accident-free. Play in Europe, America, Japan and USSR in 1830-2020. Complete the story mode from the Gold Rush of 1849 to the first manned spaceflight, and then explore the random mode. Management. Construction. Trains. Welcome to Train Valley!
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows XP (SP3)+ (can crash in Win10) Processor: Intel Core 2 Duo E4500 @ 2.2GHz or AMD Athlon 64 X2 5600+ @ 2.8 GHz Memory: 2 GB RAM Graphics: ATi Radeon HD 2400 or NVIDIA GeForce 7600 or better DirectX: Version 9.0c Storage: 1 GB available space

reviews.review_text: What is it?

I've been looking for something to scratch the Transport / Railroad Tycoon itch for a while now, and although there are some potentially promising games on the horizon, it seemed like there were no good examples in the genre at the moment.  And then I stumbled upon Train Valley, which, within a few minutes of playing confirms that the above is true - this isn't a tycoon game. What it is, is a puzzle game - and once you get a few levels in, it's fiendish. It conjurs up the correct mix of raising a smile when things go to plan, and swearing at your screen when you get overwhelmed and the inevitable happens - and trains crash.  The premise is simple; you are given a grid and two coloured stations on each map, and you drag lines from one to the other, avoiding or bulldozing (at a cost) your way through buildings and trees, some of which are randomly placed whilst some are always in the same place. Trains will spawn in the stations with a colour indicating that they want you to direct them to the other station, you click to launch the train and it makes its way down the track and you get paid when it arrives - each train has a value which ticks down from the moment it spawns to the moment it arrives at the destination. The complexity comes in as the map progresses. New stations will spawn on the map - in predetermined positions but in a random order, and begin to spawn trains all eager to go somewhere else. You will lay more tracks, launch trains, and use the track switches to try and avoid a catastrophe. Fortunately you can stop and reverse trains, but this doesn't always help if you're not keeping a good watch out - only one train can occupy a station, so it will launch itself if a second one is about to spawn.  The difficultly ramps up; early maps serve to teach you the basics and later ones cram stations in awkward places with choke points to force trains onto the same pieces of track. When things go well, it's great - but sometimes, you just can't avoid an explosion.  Back to my search for a tycoon game - even though this clearly isn't one, the art style and simple way of laying track would lend itself very well to a more in depth strategy game which, if I were the developer, I'd seriously consider.

Bought it, played five hours in one session right away. So I guess that's good.  It is not a classic 'Tycoon' game, as you might have figured out from the screenshot, more like a halfway point of that and a puzzle game like, say, Air Control. Which is good! The levels really change up the core gameplay of 'somehow get a bunch of trains from A to B without them all crashing into each other' in some interesting ways, and some of the Russian and Japanese levels require LOTS of concentration.  I would say I had more fun with this than with many of the 'real' railway management sims. Two things, though:  * I'd like to have more content. There's enough right now to justify the price point, but after going through most of the levels, I'd still like to go on. So give me some DLC and I'll buy that stuff. * There are still some glitches, which also occasionally forced me to restart levels. It is annoying as hell, but because I like the core gameplay so much, I can still recommend it. I hope there will be improvements, though. (EDIT: Yay, there have been indeed.)

I'm writing this review after finishing 100%.  Overall the game is a solid puzzle game with two main components: management of time and management of space. I would recommend this for anyone enjoying puzzle games.  Main positives: - solid amount of content - achievements are sensible and are actually a good challenge  Main negatives: - the randomized nature of the levels can be annoying at times - can feel very dry and repetitive
A very simple, yet elegant game. I would not recommend taking this game as seriously as I did as watching my trains crash over and over lead me to dub it as a 'Heart Attack Simulator'.

Not sure if you've ever played 'Sid Meier's Railroads' but it's a much more simplified version of that (and that game was fairly simple to begin with!). Someone also compared it to 'Lionel's(?) Train Town' which is also a fair comparison to make!  To start with, it's not a tycoon game so don't be fooled by the images if they look like a Railroad Tycoon. The game is more focused on being a puzzle game based around trains. I'm sure if you've played Railroad Tycoon or the like you've had to overcome complicated junctions or network improvements the puzzles tend to focus on that skill - placing stations in awkward places.   Every so often the game will general a train which will be at one of the stations (there's a gauge timer thing at the bottom right of the screen so you can see when the next train will generate) - you can also call on addional trains to create additional revenue. The train will be assigned a colour and you have to create a route via the switches/junctions you've made in your solution to get the train to it's destination. Laying track and destroying objects costs money and, along with a tax you have to pay, your balance can deplete quickly - going below 0 results in bankrupcy and you lose the game.  There are four different regions progressing in difficulty. Difficulty in this game is present through awkwardly placed stations, objects to either neogotiate around or destroy and build over at an addition cost (depends on what you destroy for cost) and the challenges present in each level (spend x money, don't let trains go to the wrong stations, etc) create some replayability.  This is a fun puzzler and the trains were just a bonus (well, at least for me anyway).

English than Portuguese  From someone if 27.6 hours played and who finished the game with all the ' Stamps' and completed as All the Achievements (with exception of those in dlc )  English: I believe it is important to tell those interested in buying this game that, although it is a very good game, is not exactly a train simulator. If you exchange the stations for water records, the tracks for pipes and the trains for water, the game operation would remain exactly the same (!), so, it´s a puzzle that uses the 'skin' of trains . In the end, you don´t do nothing but have to come up with a way to take the trains (replaceable by any other object) from point 'A' to 'B' point. The criticism is because I bought the game having in mind something like the old Railroad Tycoon II, and there is absolutely nothing of his features here. There is no management of the trains. You indicates your ways and just take care of the break. The connection of the tracks is simple, limiting creativity in creating lines (intersections) more complex. There is no freedom to choose which trains to use, which loads carry loads, which station is more important to get that load, and so on .... it is a puzzle where you connect points. A very good and even challenging at times, but a puzzle. Not a simulator. Likes puzzles, go ahead. Expect something more than a puzzle ... better pass or run the risk in a very good sale.  Português:  Para indicar minha experiência com o jogo, tenho 27.6hr. de jogadas e terminei todas as fases, cumprindo com todos os desafios (são três por fase). Tenho todas as conquistas existentes com exceção daquelas constantes na dlc  Acredito que seja importante avisar àqueles interessados na compra deste jogo que, apesar de se tratar de um game muito bom, não é exatamente um simulador de trens. Se você trocar as estações por registros de água, os trilhos por canos e e os trens por água, o funcionamento do jogo continuaria sendo exatamente o mesmo (!), ou seja, trata-se de um puzzle que utiliza a 'skin' de trens. No final das contas, vc. não faz nada além de ter de bolar uma maneira de levar os trens (substituíveis por qualquer outro objeto) do ponto 'A' ao ponto 'B'. A crítica fica pq. comprei o jogo tendo em mente algo como o antigo Railroad Tycoon II, e não existe absolutamente nenhuma característica deste. Não há administração dos trens. Você dita seus caminhos e no máximo os pausa.  A conexão dos trilhos é bem simples o que limita a criatividade na criação de linhas mais complexas (cruzamentos mais complexos). Não há liberdade para escolher que trens usar, os evoluir/melhorar, que cargas levar, para onde levar, a importância da carga para aquele local e assim por diante.... se trata de um puzzle de conectar pontos. Um muito bom e até desafiador às vezes, porém, um puzzle. Não um simulador. Curte Puzzles, vá em frente. Espera algo mais do que um quebra-cabeça... melhor deixar passar ou correr o risco em uma sale muito boa.
Beautiful!   ...but...  This game causes braindamage, because of excessive multitasking.

Pro's + easy gameplay of starting/stopping/reversing trains, setting switches and building new railways + the feeling of those near-miss moments, well planned two way railways and 'roundabouts' + the rocket launch (I didn't even notice it until after it happened) + levels change on a restart of the same level  Mixed - not a lot of different trains; I would've liked more real trains and some sort of collectors book-ish element - the graphics of the levels; often you're just to busy managing your routes to notice it though  Con's - the UI; would've been visually easier to have all the elements in the top center - the menu's look really bad to me, I like the concept of the history book and stamps though - some special trains are sometimes pushing waiting trains out of the station without notice or countdown timer; happens only on a few levels  Recommended + pausing the game while building tracks ;) + classical music (for stress relief) playlist via Youtube + spending the money you earn on improving your railways (layout)  Still unsure? There's a demo that represents the game well (played that about 3 hours before purchase as well)

Once I realized that this was primarily a puzzle game with Trains and not really a railroad simulation, I changed my expectations and enjoyed this game. It is a fairly quick game, and it can be a challenge to track (pun intended) which switches are needed in what order for each train.   The only thing I have trouble with are pop-up buildings that made it nearly impossible to see which way the switch was aligned. Other than that, it works as advertised.  I enjoyed this game!

First thing I want to say - this is very good game. It is build with simple mechanics that turns into gameplay with pretty high difficulty at the last levels. Be prepared to restart a lot at the second half of the game. It's hard to compare with any game that I've played, but there is one, which is basically the same - old DOS game called Short Lines from 1992. I have spent a lot of time playing ShortLine and I really wanted something more modern - Train Valley is exactly that.  Of course It has a few thing, that I'd like to be improved - bigger maps; better UX (sometimes it hard to click on train to launch it or on switch etc.); music, better turn it off once you get to the settings; more variety. I will hope on Train Valley 2, but, unfortunatly, it looks like we will not get it soon :(  Thanks guys for the grate game, I will recommended to my frieds ;)
Great game
Train Valley is a small, but challenging game. It's not about hard management or city building. It's about railroads and trains at all. Very simple to start playing, but hard to win.
Hard for the first timers (may or not be myself), it is very fun and challenging at the same time

Like others have said it isn't a train management game, it's a puzzle game, but it's a really good one. The graphics are great and not too taxing on a system, which means I can start it up and have a quick play in seconds. Dipping in and out is no problem and replaying some of the easier levels takes on a zen-like quality.   The game is charming, with good music and sound effects and a really great design, essentially like looking at a really good train set!  I was playing on level 9 or so and made a really elegant rail system, so when I didn't notice I had two trains on the same path until too late I literally cried out! All I'm saying is that any game that can get that sort of reaction is a good game.   My one critisism is that the first time I played my progress was lost because I wasn't syncing to the cloud. But thats a small complaint because it was easy t o fix.
If you like trains and enjoy a good puzzle game this is for you. I find it somewhat relaxing, but there are definitely some moments that will have you stressed if you aren't paying attention!

Completely fun, compelling, and encouraging compulsive play. I have been playing it every night. I do not regret purchasing it. It is a fun experience of train traffic management.    Rough around the edges though. The missions are absolutely homogenous. Any difference between the 'Japan' and 'wherever else' missions was lost on me. Considering how interchangeable and unmemorable the missions are, I am a little surprised there were not twice as many. The experience is compelling, so I want more. And some tiered achievements would encourage level replay -- the levels are easy to triple-crown the first time through. So what am I going to replay them for? I would like to replay them so that I can get Super Platinum Ultra but there is no such possibility.    It could use a bit more polish. The trains enter buildings, and you can see them pop-out. This hurts my eyes. Please do not do this. Pop them out once they are completely hidden from the player.    And you're allowed to build train tracks where future train stations will appear, spontaneously, without warning. Why would this be allowed? It is completely disruptive to train traffic when a train station suddenly blocks the way. This is completely opaque and unpredictable for the player. It is the 'blue shell' of Train Valley.   So, the game is broken in a few ways, but I still couldn't stop playing it. Your mileage may vary.
Best game together with kids.
The John Deere Bulldozers in 1855 are really what makes this game for me. I can't express to you the joy I feel every time I see one. Thank you based Flazm!
Really fun puzzle game with a lot of variability. My three year old daughter just loved watching.

Simple and elegant management game where it's very easy to understand what to do. You make railroads and manage the switches. The game tells you exactly what you need to know and when something goes wrong it is always the players fault for not paying attention or from overconfidence.

Keep in mind that this is a game about micromanaging trains, not a strategy/'tycoon' game. This game is quite fun, but quite short of you don't like completing all the challenges in the game.  I picked this game up during a Steam sale for €7.00 including DLC. I would say that it was worth that money, but I am not sure if I would recommend it at full price (€12.50).  Pros: - The core mechanics, laying rails and directing trains, are easy to understand and work reasonably well - The theming is great - The levels are designed well, making it a challenge to find the optimal layout of tracks to complete all challenges - The game is not incredibly difficult. The 6 levels added by the DLC are somewhat harder than the 24 in the base game. The ability to pause the game makes it a lot less stressful too.  Cons: - The music is repetitive, and while soothing it just annoyed me after a while. - Rail junctions work... weird. Rail junctions are blocked when a train is on top of them. However, the game also blocks rail junctions on adjecent rails, or even crossing rails. - The challenges get stale after a bit. The challenges for Germany have some more fun ones in them, such as blowing up 5 trains. - The sandbox mode is completely broken, with train stations not showing up at all. Besides that, it's not all that fun without a clear goal or even money to worry about. - Even after completing every challenge, and completing every other achievement, I only built about 9000 train tracks towards the 'build 10.000 train tracks' achievement. Luckily the game counts train tracks built just before restarting a level, so building a lot of useless tracks on a level with high starting money solves that problem, but 'grinding building train tracks' is not fun nor won't it give me a sense of achieving something on reaching it.
At first , i thought this was gonna be a casual and relaxing game , apparently , i was wrong af

While it might not look like it but Train Valley is one of the best puzzle games that I have played in quite a while.  What makes Train Valley stand out is that while it is pretty simplistic it is still challenging. All you do in the game is build tracks and guide the trains towards their destination. The fun comes from creating the routes and juggling multiple trains at the same time while trying to keep them from crashing into one another and running out of money. Train Valley does a great job of being a relaxing game that still challenges you.  I would classify Train Valley as an easy to play but hard to master game. It is not that hard to beat the levels in Train Valley but it becomes quite hard to 100% some of the later levels so there is quite a bit of challenge if you want it. Length wise the game includes 24 levels and should take at least six to eight hours to complete. I found Train Valley enjoyable enought though that I actually wanted to try and complete as many of the additional objectives as I could which can add quite a bit of time to the game.   If you are looking for a train simulation game or don't really like puzzle games, Train Valley is not going to be for you. If the game's premise sounds interesting though I think you will really enjoy Train Valley.   If you would like to read my full review check out   Geeky Hobbies   [www.geekyhobbies.com]  .

Its short real time puzzle-strategy game . I kept on coming back to it and I had a lot of fun. Its addictive game, and if you have free 10-15 min for a little game break from work its for you. You can come back to it many times each day.

I love thies indie stratgey games like this, They start you off easy and then it gets hard as you go.  -Graphics 6/10 -Game Play 9/10 -Map Themes 10/10 -Controls 9/10  Over All 10/10 Best Indie train simulation of the year

This game is very addicting. If you like trains and puzzle games that makes your brain tingle, this game is for you. Some maps are easy, some are hard. But the overall difficulty is good. Not too many maps, though. I've yet to try the DLC.

This game is kind of 'meh' type of game.  It has a really weird loose condition: you can't have negative balance, like in all other economy based games, resulting in regular and spontaneous 'You are bankrupt' pop ups, while you have 4 really expensive trains on there way to the stations. Usually it happens because you had to expand new rail tracks really long to a new trains station and spend all the money. And than after a minute the tax comes and makes you a bankrupt. So you have to always keep an amount of money on your bank account to not let it happen, though the amount is always growing during the level, so you have to guess or loose. Can't imagine play testers did not mention it while on development.   It also has a typical Unity bug: it works really terrible on a dual monitor PC. So you are most likely have to change windows registry to be able to play the game. Also, the devs were not of a particular help here.  The UI even on a regular 1920p monitor is tiny and unintuitive. I have a 27' monitor and it's hard to spot most essential gameplay information when you need to. The tools icons are like 20 pixels at the top of the screen and the new train icon on the station (most essential gameplay ui element in the game) is like 5.  Track building tools are rather unresponsive, far from polished.  The lack of a proper tutorial is a pain also.  It's sad, that developers didn't put enough effort here. The game plays rather nice even with all these problems.
One of those simple yet incredibly fun games.

this game is great really good to relax and listen to podcasts to
Charming, accessible and adequately challanging. Each level feels new and fresh, and the achievments are balanced and attainable! Highly recommended for any puzzle player!

A Strangly Addictive Game  I bought this game looking for something like the old-schoold game Atrain (DOS) and when I first launched it, I was disapointed as it wasn't like that. But that's okay as it never was promised as such and I didn't read the description before purchasing it. With the amount of positive reviews it has, it was a sure buy - and it has trains.  I was instantly hooked on the game once I got the overall concept and how the game worked. It's a game like none other I have played despite having the same concepts as others. But it is unique in the method of which everything is applied.  Train Valley is a simple game as-is, but that doesn't make it easy. It can be a very challenging game and you'll spend a lot of time getting those last few stamps. With a relative small map, you have to build train tracks between given stations and change the tracks to direct your trains towards the proper station. That in itself would be easy if you had unlimited money, time, and space - but you don't - and that's where the challenge lies.  It would have been nice with a few more levels and maybe a few bigger ones, but for a sales price it's more than enough content and you can have hundreds of hours entertainment for very little money.
